exam.source: National Center For University Entrance Examination
exam.subject: SekaishiB(main exam)

exam:
Center-2007--Main-WorldHistoryB
2007 Academic Year Main Examination: World History B
[1]
Pilgrimages to religious sites and sacred places began to flourish as information about those places was gathered and transport links to them developed. Read the following texts A-C, which relate to visits to religious sites and the social phenomena to which they gave rise, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(25 points)
A
Santiago de Compostela, which is located in the Galicia region in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula, is an important place of pilgrimage in (1)Christianity.In the 9th century, a grave believed to be that of James, one of the apostles of Jesus, was discovered there and it became a Christian religious site, which began to be visited by many pilgrims from across Europe.A pilgrimage route called the "Way of St. James" developed and James came to be venerated as the patron saint of (2)pilgrims and travelers.At the same time, as the (3)Reconquista (reconquest and recovery of territory) on the Iberian Peninsula gathered pace, he also began to be positioned as the patron saint of Christians fighting against infidels.
Question 1
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the underlined portion (1).
1
(1)It was established based on the teachings of Jesus, who criticized Islam.
(2)Its holy book is the New Testament.
(3)It was made the state religion by the Emperor Diocletian.
(4)Wycliffe was declared a heretic at the Council of Clermont (ecumenical council).
Question 2
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes travel and voyages in regard to the underlined portion (2).
2
(1)Columbus reached Kozhikode (Calicut) with the support of Queen Isabella of Spain.
(2)Cook explored the Pacific islands with the support of King John II of Portugal.
(3)Cabral was washed ashore in Brazil and claimed it as Portuguese territory.
(4)Livingstone explored the African interior and visited the Kingdom of Aksum.
Question 3
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the Iberian Peninsula when the underlined portion (3) took place.
3
(1)The king of the Visigothic Kingdom, which became independent from the Abbasid Caliphate, was called the Caliph.
(2)The Kingdom of Aragon was founded in the west of the Iberian Peninsula.
(3)The Almohad Caliphate, which advanced into the Iberian Peninsula, was overthrown by the Almoravid dynasty.
(4)The Nasrid dynasty built the Alhambra palace in Granada.
B
There are quite a few inscriptions by pilgrims on the stone pillars at (4)Angkor Wat in Cambodia.There are even a few written in ink by visitors from such Japanese provinces as Hizen, Higo and Sakai, during the first half of the 17th century.Of these, the inscription by Morimoto Ukondayu Kazufusa (see picture below) is particularly famous; in 1632, he wrote that he made offerings to four images of the Buddha, to pray for his parents’ future years.It is said that it was then that Kazufusa copied down the arrangement of the temple buildings and brought it back home, describing it as the famous Jetavana (Gion Shoja) Buddhist monastery that appears in the "Tale of the Heike".It appears that pilgrims from Japan at that time mistook Angkor Wat for a place in India where (5)Siddhartha Gautama taught.At any rate, the only reason why it became possible to visit this area as a "Buddhist religious site" is that trading ships licensed by the shogunate (6)at that time were traveling between Japan and Southeast Asia.
Question 4
From 1-4 below, choose the most appropriate sentence concerning the underlined portion (4).
4
(1)It was built by the Srivijaya Kingdom.
(2)It was built during the same period as the Vardhana dynasty ruled in India.
(3)It was built by Chandragupta II.
(4)It was originally built as a Hindu temple.
Question 5
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the propagation of the teachings of the figure referred to in the underlined portion (5).
5
(1)In India, Mahayana Buddhism spread during the rule of the Mauryan dynasty.
(2)In China, Xuanzang traveled to India and brought home the Buddhist scriptures during the Tang period.
(3)In Indonesia, Theravada Buddhism spread during the rule of the Pagan Kingdom.
(4)On the Korean Peninsula, Buddhism was first introduced during the Joseon (Yi dynasty) period.
Question 6
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes Southeast Asia from the latter half of the 16th century until the first half of the 17th century in regard to the underlined portion (6).
6
(1)Manila was a Spanish trading post.
(2)The Tran dynasty was established in Vietnam.
(3)On the Malay Peninsula, the Malacca Sultanate prospered through maritime trade.
(4)In Thailand, the Sukhothai Kingdom prospered through trade.
C
The (7)Islamic pilgrimage not only had a religious significance, but also had an important political meaning.Moreover, due to the expansion of Islam and the development of means of transport, pilgrims from distant lands also began to participate.(8)Kotaro Yamaoka, who is said to have been the first Japanese pilgrim to Mecca, developed a deeper interest in Islam through his interactions with an ulama (Muslim scholar), who was seeking the liberation of Muslims from the rule of the Russian Empire.In 1909, on his first journey of pilgrimage, which he undertook under the guidance of this ulama, he visited Mecca, traveling via South Asia.He later recorded in his book that he received an unexpected welcome during this visit to Mecca, as a "citizen of the victorious nation" in the (9)Russo-Japanese War.
Question 7
From 1-4 below, choose the one correct word to fill the gaps marked (A) in the sentences below in regard to the underlined portion (7).
7
1
During the 8th century, the (A) movement, which advocated returning to the teachings of Muhammad, began on the Arabian Peninsula.The (A) movement triggered the spread via pilgrims of a Muslim revivalist movement in each area.
(1)Twelver Shi'ism
(2)Nestorianism
(3)Wahhabism
(4)Presbyterianism
Question 8
From 1-6 below, choose the one correct combination of positions a~c on the map below that indicates the locations referred to in sentences (A) and (B) below, which describe the cities through which the figure referred to in underlined portion (8) traveled on his pilgrimage.
8
(A)- Muhammad undertook a hijra to this city.
(B)- This city prospered as the capital of the Umayyad Caliphate.
(1)(A)-a(B)-b
(2)(A)-a(B)-c
(3)(A)-b(B)-a
(4)(A)-b(B)-c
(5)(A)-c(B)-a
(6)(A)-c(B)-b
Question 9
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the underlined portion (9).
9
(1)This war was triggered by Bloody Sunday.
(2)As a result of this war, Japan captured Taiwan and Penghu.
(3)During the presidency of the President of the United States of America who mediated in this war, Hawaii was absorbed into the United States of America.
(4)In the peace treaty ending this war, Japan was granted hegemony (predominant rights) over Korea.
[2]
Throughout history, humans have had links to various organisms. Above all, they have had deep relationships with domesticated animals, something that has had a major influence not only on their societies and cultures, but sometimes even on their approaches to their nations. Read the following texts A-C, which relate to the relationships between humans and domestic animals, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(25 points)
A
Horses were domesticated around 6,000 years ago, with horses beginning to pull chariots in about 2,000 BCE.When horse riding (see picture below) spread due to improvements in the bits attached to bridles, (1)nomadic tribes on horseback emerged on the Eurasian continent.Their elusive character became a major threat to sedentary agricultural societies, so troops mounted on horseback were organized to counteract them.Rulers who sought good horses also emerged, such as (2)Emperor Wu of Han, who sought Ferghana horses, and horses became an important item in trade between agricultural peoples and nomads.Moreover, the (3)Mongol Empire expanded its territory through its powerful horseback-mounted troops and developed a post horse system, which facilitated the traffic of people and goods across the whole of Eurasia.
Question 1
In regard to the underlined portion (1), from 1-4 below, choose the one name that correctly describes the nomadic tribe on horseback that came to prominence in the 6th century and built up a nation.
10
(1)1 Scythians
(2)2 Göktürks
(3)3 Yuezhi
(4)4 Xiongnu
Question 2
From 1-4 below, choose that one sentence that correctly describes the achievements of the emperor referred to in the underlined portion (2).
11
(1)He transferred the capital to Luoyang and attached importance to the domestic administration of the country.
(2)He established a national monopoly on items such as salt and iron, and sought to adjust and stabilize prices.
(3)He unified the systems of writing, weights and measures, and currency.
(4)He promulgated the commandery-county system and established the Three Departments and Six Ministries system.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes events that occurred under Mongol rule.
12
(1)Ögedei Khan destroyed the Jin dynasty and established the capital at Karakorum.
(2)Under the Yuan dynasty, the Shoushi Calendar was created, influenced by science in the Muslim world.
(3)Under Yuan rule, Han Chinese were favored, while the Semu caste from the Western Regions were despised.
(4)The Grand Canal that had been built previously was repaired, and new canals were built that ran to large cities.
B
There are two theories regarding the domestication of sheep.One is that they were first domesticated (4)approximately 9,000 years ago in western Asia, in order to supplement the unstable agricultural economy.The other is that nomads managing domestic animals emerged as the hunting peoples of inland Asia followed flocks of wild sheep and acquired the skills of milking and castrating them.At any rate, domesticated sheep were prized by both agricultural peoples and nomads as "walking" portable food, while their wood was treasured as (5)the raw material for making woolen cloth.In Mongolia, spilling the blood of a sheep on the land was viewed as taboo, a belief that developed because (6)Genghis Khan stipulated in a law that "a different method than that used in Islam shall be used".Thus, perspectives on nature and religion were also reflected in the relationship with sheep.
Question 4
From 1-4 below, choose the most appropriate sentence concerning events during the time referred to in the underlined portion (4).
13
(1)The city-states of the Sumerians began to be formed.
(2)The Neanderthals emerged.
(3)The Bronze Age began.
(4)The ice age ended and the climate began to warm up.
Question 5
In regard to the underlined portion (5), from 1-4 below, choose the correct combination of words that fit into the gaps marked (A) and (B) in the texts below concerning wool production in Europe.
14
In England in the first half of the 16th century, exports of woolen cloth to (A) in the region of Flanders increased sharply, so there was a rise in enclosure focused on eliminating common land and converting land from arable to pasture, in order to increase wool production.As a result, the economy became more dynamic and a class of landowners called (B) arose.
(1)(A)- Antwerpen (Antwerp) (B)- Yeomen
(2)(A)- Antwerpen (Antwerp) (B)- Gentry
(3)(A)- Hamburg(B)- Yeomen
(4)(A)- Hamburg(B)- Gentry
Question 6
In regard to the underlined portion (6), from 1-4 below, choose the one term that correctly describes the religion that was established after the time of Genghis Khan.
15
(1)Taoism
(2)Christianity
(3)Sikhism
(4)Buddhism
C
The picture on the Christmas card showing a pig pulling Santa Claus's sleigh can be described as an example illustrating the close relationship between pigs and people in Europe (see the picture below).Before modern times, when livestock began to be raised in barns, pigs in (7))agricultural communities were turned out into the forests to forage, and they also ran freely through city streets.When winter came, the fattened pigs were captured and turned into salt-cured meat or sausages. In contrast, the consumption of this meat is prohibited under the precepts of Judaism and Islam.(8)In India in the latter half of the 19th century, a large-scale rebellion against colonial rule took place; one of the things that triggered this was the fact that Muslim soldiers revolted due to a rumor that pork fat had been used on the cartridges in their guns.
Question 7
In regard to the underlined portion (7), from 1-4 below, choose the most appropriate sentence that describes agriculture and farmers in Europe.
16
(1)The three-field system of agriculture was popularized in the 6th century, increasing agricultural production.
(2)The Black Death (plague) epidemic dramatically reduced the farming population in the 12th century.
(3)The peasant revolt called Jacquerie occurred in France in the 14th century.
(4)Under the system of domain economies based on compulsory labor (Gutsherrschaft), grain was produced for export to Eastern Europe.
Question 8
From 1-4 below, choose the most appropriate sentence concerning the underlined portion (8).
17
(1)This rebellion is also called the Sipahi (Sepoy) Mutiny.
(2)In the midst of this rebellion, Gandhi conducted his campaign of passive resistance.
(3)The Ever Victorious Army was actively involved in suppressing this rebellion.
(4)After this rebellion, Queen Victoria also became the empress of the Mughal Empire.
Question 9
In regard to the same underlined portion (8), from 1-4 below, choose the correct combination of "correct" and "incorrect" in regard to the following sentences a and b concerning the independence of colonies following the Second World War.
18
aIraq became independent.bMozambique became independent.
(1)a- Correctb- Correct
(2)a- Correctb- Incorrect
(3)a- Incorrectb- Correct
(4)a- Incorrectb- Incorrect
[3]
Nations have used symbols and legends concerning their founding and have created ideals in order to assert their legitimacy. Read the following texts A-C, which relate to such legends, symbols and ideals concerning nations, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(25 points)
A
During the early Western Han dynasty, Jia Yi criticized the "rule of law" under the First Emperor, writing that, "he augmented his own power, made the penal code harsher, put military might ahead of the path of humanity and justice, and used tyranny as his primary means of ruling the country".During the (1)Ming dynasty, Zhou Jingxin said, "The length of time for which a nation prospers depends on its level of virtue. The (2)Han, Tang and Song dynasties lasted a long time, while dynasties such as Qin and Sui were short-lived; those that govern justly are long-lasting, while those that betray that principle are cut short".In other words, the "virtue" of its rulers was deemed to determine the fate of a nation. It was thought that key to a peaceful reign lay in the outstanding moral character of an emperor or dynasty, even if control over the nation had been gained by means of military might.The principle of "rule by virtue", which lasted for a long time in China, until the fall of the Qing dynasty (3)in the early 20th century, can be seen in this.
Question 1
From 1-4 below, choose the correct combination of words that fit into the gaps marked (A) and (B) in the sentences below describing events that occurred during the period referred to in the underlined portion (1).
19
During the latter half of the Ming period, many missionaries from Europe began to visit China.(B), who belonged to the Society of Jesus (Jesuits), which was established by (A), did not only engage in missionary work, but also drew up the Kunyu Wanguo Quantu (Map of the Myriad Countries of the World), which played a part in showing China the extent of the world.
(1)(A)- Zwingli(B)- Matteo Ricci
(2)(A)- Zwingli(B)- Müntzer
(3)(A)- Ignatius of Loyola(B)- Matteo Ricci
(4)(A)- Ignatius of Loyola(B)- Müntzer
Question 2
From 1-4 below, in regard to the underlined portion (2), choose the correct name of the era that lasted from the fall of the Tang dynasty until the establishment of the Song dynasty, in which there was a succession of short-lived dynasties and small independent states were established.
20
(1)The Warring States period
(2)The Sixteen Kingdoms period
(3)The Southern and Northern Dynasties period
(4)The Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period
Question 3
From 1-4 below, choose the one incorrect sentence concerning events that occurred during the time referred to in the underlined portion (3).
21
(1)Outer Mongolia declared its independence at the time of the Xinhai Revolution.
(2)The Chinese government refused to sign the Treaty of Versailles.
(3)The policy of "alliance with Soviet Russia, co-operation with the Communist Party, and assistance to the workers and peasants" was set forth by Sun Yat-sen.
(4)In Taiwan, the Tungning family surrendered to the Qing dynasty.
B
Various legends surround the founding of the United States of America.For example, the tale that a woman called Betsy Ross made the Stars and Stripes flag, which is the (4)national flag of the United States of America, at the request of George Washington is believed to be a legend that soon became widely believed to be true, stemming from a story that began to be told almost a hundred years after the nation achieved independence(see picture below).Moreover, the (5)Declaration of Independence document contained in the National Archives was not drawn up on the Fourth of July, which became American Independence Day; in fact, the document was signed the following month.However, both the former Presidents Adams and Jefferson died on the Fourth of July, on the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, so that date became even more sacrosanct.Subsequently, (6)President Monroe also died on the Fourth of July, on the 55th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
Question 4
Regarding the underlined portion (4), the Stars and Stripes flag in the picture has 13 stars and 13 stripes, representing the 13 colonies that became independent as the United States of America.From 1-4 below, choose the name of the place that was not one of those 13 colonies.
22
(1)Massachusetts
(2)New York
(3)Virginia
(4)Florida
Question 5
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the American Revolution in regard to the underlined portion (5).
23
(1)Thomas Paine published "Common Sense".
(2)Jefferson was appointed commander-in-chief of the armies of the 13 colonies.
(3)Great Britain participated in the League of Armed Neutrality.
(4)The British Army won the Siege of Yorktown.
Question 6
From 1-4 below, choose the most appropriate combination of words that fit into the gaps marked (A) and (B) in the sentences below concerning the president referred to in the underlined portion (6).
24
In December 1823, in the annual State of the Union Address to Congress, he advocated a diplomatic policy focused on such matters as nonintervention between (A) and (B).This is called the Monroe Doctrine.
(1)(A)- The Americas(B)- Asia
(2)(A)- The Americas(B)- Europe
(3)(A)- The African continent(B)- Asia
(4)(A)- The African continent(B)- Europe
C
During the(7)French Revolution, in Paris, a new concept of a nation was articulated: the republic.The Church of St. Geneviève was renamed the Panthéon and it became the burial place of (8)Enlightenment thinkers and revolutionaries, where they were commemorated and mythicized (see picture below).A spacious avenue crossing central Paris linked the site of the Bastille prison with the Place de la Révolution (now known as the Place de la Concorde), and there were plans to symbolize the revolution in the city's urban spaces.This plan for the city was left unfinished, but despite subsequent restorations of the monarchy and two periods of imperial rule, the principle of republicanism gradually took root in France, leading to the (9)Fifth Republic that exists today.
Question 7
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the parliament and government during the period referred to in the underlined portion (7).
25
(1)The national assembly (National Constituent Assembly) declared war on Austria and started a battle.
(2)The Legislative Assembly was overthrown by the coup d'état of 18 Brumaire.
(3)The National Convention adopted the French Revolutionary Calendar (French Republican Calendar).
(4)The Directory executed the King and declared a republic.
Question 8
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (8).
26
(1)Montesquieu wrote "The Spirit of the Laws", in which he advocated the separation of the three branches of government.
(2)Rousseau compiled the "Encyclopédie " with Molière.
(3)Lafayette wrote "What Is the Third Estate?"
(4)Quesnay wrote "Tableau économique", in which he advocated mercantilism.
Question 9
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the foreign policy of France during the period referred to in the underlined portion (9).
27
(1)It occupied the Ruhr.
(2)It concluded the Quintuple Alliance.
(3)It permitted the independence of Algeria.
(4)It dispatched troops to Mexico.
[4]
People with shared political and economic objectives or religious beliefs have explored alliances in various forms. Read the following texts A-C, which relate to forms of alliance and organization peculiar to their respective ages and regions, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(25 points)
A
In Europe in ancient times, alliances were constructed in order to attack common enemies or as a means of defense.(1)In Ancient Greece, Athens and Sparta each formed alliances with city-states (poleis (plural of polis)), with themselves as the leaders of those alliances.In western Europe, after the collapse of the Western Roman Empire, (2)Francia quickly formed an affiliation with the Church in Rome (see the picture below), as a result of which it was able to secure new authority and capture a power base ahead of the other Germanic kingdoms.It interests coincided with those of the Pope, who required support from a secular power.Moreover, subsequently, various interests mingled in the (3)Holy Roman Empire, and a diverse range of alliances were frequently formed in relation to the policies of the Emperor, as well as in the midst of sectarian conflict.
Question 1
From 1-4 below, choose the correct name for the alliance formed with Sparta as the leader, in regard to the underlined portion (1).
28
(1)The Delian League
(2)The Peloponnesian League
(3)The League of Corinth
(4)The Quadruple Alliance
Question 2
From 1-6 below, in regard to the underlined portion (2), choose the option showing the correct sequence of events in sentences a~c below, starting with the oldest first, concerning Francia and the subsequent King of East Francia.
29
aOtto I created the rank of Holy Roman Emperor.
bClovis converted to Athanasianism (Catholicism).
cPepin became king.
(1)a→b→c
(2)a→c→b
(3)b→a→c
(4)b→c→a
(5)c→a→b
(6)c→b→a
Question 3
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the underlined portion (3).
30
(1)The cities of northern Italy formed the Lombard League and fought the emperor.
(2)Catholic powers formed the Schmalkaldic League and fought the emperor.
(3)Vassal states formed the Union of Utrecht in order to end the interregnum.
(4)The Holy Roman Emperor advocated the League of the Three Emperors, along with the Byzantine Emperor.
B
The Enlightenment in Europe brought about a new perspective on the world, which was based on an acknowledgment of the reason of humanity and the conscience of the individual, and behavior grounded in this. The intellectual background to this was the emergence of a new way for people to connect to each other, in which autonomous citizens formed groups based on their own free will, concluded agreements based on equal entitlements, and elected representatives.Such societies of citizens were supported by the (4)liberalism of the 19th century, and the revolutions of 1848 saw demands being made for "freedom of assembly" in various European cities.The development of (5)constitutional government and parliamentary systems in Europe would have been unimaginable without a political culture of such assembly.In the latter half of the 19th century, activities focused on developing organizations spread to (6)workers and farmers, who sought to protect their interests, and representatives of these groups were also sent to parliaments.
Question 4
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the underlined portion (4).
31
(1)In Germany, under the Congress of Vienna settlement, a group called the Carbonari was formed, which sought freedom and unity.
(2)As a result of the July Revolution, Belgium became independent of France.
(3)In Great Britain, the Test Acts were enacted, opening up the way for Nonconformists to take up public employment.
(4)Kossuth led the 1848 revolution (March Revolution) in Hungary.
Question 5
From 1-4 below, choose the one incorrect sentence concerning the underlined portion (5).
32
(1)In Russia, during the November (October) Revolution, the Tsar promised to establish a parliament (Duma).
(2)In Great Britain, the right to vote was extended over the course of a number of revisions of the election laws.
(3)In the German Empire, the Reichstag (imperial parliament) was elected on the basis of universal male suffrage.
(4)In France, the Third Republic was formed after the country's defeat in the Franco-Prussian War (war between France and Prussia).
Question 6
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the labor movement and socialism in Europe in regard to the underlined portion (6).
33
(1)Fourier and others organized the First International.
(2)The Soviet regime formed in Russia established the Second International.
(3)Marx and Engels published the "Manifesto of the Communist Party".
(4)Bismarck supported the socialists.
C
In China, there are many secret societies centered on religion, such as the Taiping Dao sect, which started the Yellow Turban Rebellion at the end of the Later Han period. From the Song period onward, the White Lotus Society, which believed that the Maitreya Buddha would descend to Earth and help people, spread and there were frequent rebellions that had elements that were revolutions against the existing regime.At the end of the Yuan period, (7) occurred, and the figure who emerged from this established the Ming dynasty.During the Qing period, there was an outbreak of rebellion by White Lotus Society members, in the year when the (8)Qianlong Emperor abdicated.At the end of the 19th century, the (9)Boxer Rebellion occurred and groups of women, called Red Lanterns Shining (Hongdengzhao) emerged as organizations to help the Boxers.Many were girls in their teens and they clothed themselves in costumes that looked like something out of a fairytale (see picture below); rumors even ran riot that "they flew through the sky and rained fire down on the capital cities of Russia and Japan".
Question 7
From 1-4 below, choose the correct name for the rebellion that should be inserted into the gap marked (7) in the text.
34
(1)the Chimei (Red Eyebrow) Rebellion
(2)the Huang Chao Rebellion
(3)the An Lushan Rebellion
(4)the Red Turban Rebellion
Question 8
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the reign of the emperor referred to in the underlined portion (8).
35
(1)He conquered the Zunghar Khanate.
(2)He established the "Zongli Geguo Shiwu Yamen" ("Zongli Yamen"; "Office in charge of Affairs of All Nations").
(3)He concluded the Treaty of Kyakhta with Russia.
(4)He overthrew the Khwarazmian dynasty (dynasty of Khwarazm Shahs).
Question 9
From 1-4 below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the underlined portion (9).
36
(1)The Boxer Rebellion broke out in Shanxi Province.
(2)The Boxers took "support the Qing, destroy the Foreign" as their slogan.
(3)The Portuguese Army participated in the army of the Eight Nations Alliance.
(4)Under the Convention of Peking, the stationing of foreign armed forces in Shanghai was permitted.
